utterances: Cindy works on behalf of health insurance companies, and she deals with the people who call in and want to buy individual policies.
Well, how is it going in Broward and Palm Beach Counties?
Well, I think the professor's right.
I think with some of the states frontloading coming up before February 20th - of course, February 5th, this is super, super, super-duper Tuesday.
I think that African-Americans in a lot of the Southern states, as the professor mentioned, such as South Carolina, will have more of a opportunity to have their voices heard.
But I think the Iowa caucus and the New Hampshire primary are always the first in the nation and I don't see that changing.
But if there is a benefit for the candidates trying to frontload, I think it is that more African-Americans will have their voices heard earlier rather than later in the process.
Mary?
I think that's right.
And I think that Iowa and New Hampshire will still have influence because it'll be first, and I don't think the Democratic Party will permit somebody to get ahead of New Hampshire.
And New Hampshire will probably move theirs to December if somebody tries to get ahead of them and will go to November.
They could do it on Christmas, national holiday…
Yeah.
Yeah.
Pretty soon.
Give away free gifts, you never know.
Right.
But I do think that there will be more diversity in the group of folks who go out to vote early on, and they'll have their say.
But as I said, in the end, it may turn out to those states that come last have more influence.
We'll have to see.
All right.
Well, staying with the theme of presidential politics -moving on - Bill Richardson delivered a speech at the Millennium Biltmore Hotel in L.A.
declaring his bid for the White House.
Here's a clip.
(Spanish spoken)
That is him saying: With pride, I hope to become the first Latino president of the U.S.
What do you think about this bid?
Do you think, first of all, that he is gunning for the vice presidency by running for president?
And secondly, how much way does he have as a Latino in a race where so many people from both major parties are trying to appeal to Latinos?
Mary first.
I think that he won't be the first Latino president even if he wins, because Jimmy Smits in ""The West Wing"" was the first…
(Soundbite of laughter)
…Latino president.
But having said that - and Bill Richardson is a very attractive candidate - but he has to emphasize that he is a Hispanic because his name is Richardson and a lot of Hispanics don't know that.
So unlike Barack Obama, who doesn't have to emphasize that he is black and they're both running toward the middle, Richardson has to come out and play that card of trying to say who he is.
But if he does - I think he will appeal to a lot of Hispanics in the race and a lot of other people because he's a man with wide, broad experience, is one the most experienced…
Give us a sense of some of those different roles he's played over time.
Well, he's been U.N.
ambassador, he was secretary of energy, he's governor of a state, and the American public always likes governors to run for office for the presidency.
It's much rarer to have senators and, for gosh sake, not a congressman be elected to president of the United States.
So he has all of this going for him, a very attractive guy.
And the Hispanic factor is just an extra measure that might help him.
Ron, I just have to interject something completely inappropriate, but…
MR. CHRISTIE: Of course.
…you are a political talking head - both of you are, you go on TV - I've noticed that Bill Richardson cannot get decent makeup.
There is something going on…
(Soundbite of laughter)
…with the ethnic angle.
These makeup artists are turning him orange.
I would say to the Richardson campaign, whatever else you do, don't let the makeup artist get to you.
I say this as someone who does occasionally my share of TV.
But that's my personal digression, you know, standing up for people of color on television.
What do you think about the prospects of Richardson as a key candidate on a split ticket with someone like Barack Obama or Hillary Clinton or John Edwards?
Well, I think people are underestimating Bill Richardson.
As the professor just said a moment ago, for goodness' sakes, you haven't had a senator elected president of the United States since John Kennedy back in 1960.
Americans seem to like governors living from one executive mansion to the other.
But looking at Richardson's credentials, for goodness' sakes, he's one of the most qualified people who's out there running on the Democrat ledger.
He has vast foreign affairs experience.
He's traveled overseas numerous times.
He's widely respected in North Korea, a country that has a very important relationship with the United States as we look at trying to ameliorate relations in that part of the world.
So, I don't think - to answer your first question - that he is running for the number two spot.
I think he's running for number one, and I think he has a strong chance of breaking out of the pack.
But if you look and you say, Ron, who's going to be on the ticket?
It wouldn't surprise me if Governor Richardson's on the ticket in one way, shape or form for the Democrats come the nomination process.
All right, we have one minute and 47 seconds left.
I want to ask you about the border fence.
There's big immigration bill circulating on Capitol Hill.
One thing that Bill Richardson said was that if he's elected president, if there is some move to build up this fence, he would tear it down.
Quickly, quickly, quickly, Ron, what's your read?
Mary, what's your read on that specific provision?
I think that the fence provision is too small rather than too large.
The bill that the Congress signed into law last year provided for 700 miles.
The new legislation calls for 370.
The United States needs to improve the sovereignty of its border.
No.
...celebrating, is right?
I think that the fence is a bad idea for environmental reasons, for the animals, the endangered species, as well as the fact that it won't keep people from coming across.
Nothing keeps people from coming across somewhere other.
That's the way immigration goes.
As long there's a pool of jobs and the push of bad economic conditions at home, immigrants are going to keep coming to the United States.

It's just a bad part of a bill that is flawed, but it's likely to pass, at least in the Senate, because the lion in winter, Ted Kennedy, has come forward to say this is the best shot, so I'm going to take it.
All right.
On that note, Mary and Ron, thanks so much.
Thanks, Farai.
Thank you, Farai.
Mary Frances Berry if a professor of history at the University of Pennsylvania, and Ron Christie is vice president of the lobbying firm D.C.
Navigators and former special assistant to President George W.
Bush.
Both guests joined me from NPR's Washington D.C.
headquarters.
(Soundbite of music)
Just ahead, Sex and Sexuality in America's black colleges and universities, and looking for signs of faith with photographer Sam Fentress.
Saul Mindiola, mucho gusto.
Saul Mindiola is running for mayor of Pueblo Bello.
That means beautiful village in Spanish, a name inspired by the snowcapped Sierra Nevada mountains that surround this farm town of 16,000 residents.
(Speaking Spanish).
Mindiola, who grew up in the mountains, is a member of the Arhuaco indigenous group.
The Arhuacos have long distrusted Colombian politics.
Mindiola is the group's first-ever mayoral candidate.
(Speaking Spanish).
Mindiola wears the Arhuaco's traditional robes and woven white hat.
And even while addressing voters, he constantly chews coca leaves.
But he's got a college degree in business administration.
On the campaign stump, he speaks earnestly about women's rights and the environment.
But Mindiola fears he will lose due to electoral fraud.
He claims his main rival is illegally bussing in people from other towns and paying them to register as voters in Pueblo Bello.
(Speaking Spanish).
It's not the residents of Pueblo Bello who will elect the mayor, but people who are brought in from the outside,"" Mindiola tells me.
Watchdog groups say widespread vote-buying and voter registration fraud could affect the outcome in nearly half of Colombia's towns and cities.
Many are remote, making the electoral process difficult to monitor.
What's more, impoverished residents often sell their votes for cash or favors.
You vote for whoever gives you a little bit of groceries, a little construction material, a little bit of money.
But you don't vote for the best person that benefits the community.
That's just insane.
Unfortunately, that's been the logic here.
Andres Ceballos works for the Bogota-based Electoral Observation Mission.
He says it's vital for voters to choose wisely.
The new crop of mayors will be involved in disarming the guerrillas and other key programs under a peace treaty.
This is what's going to define - especially now that we're in the midst of peace talks - who's going to implement at the local level whatever's agreed to.
But in Pueblo Bello, free from rebel attacks for the past decade, voters have more immediate concerns.
(Speaking Spanish).
